questions.question_text:
A network security engineer configured IP multicast in the virtual router to support a new application. Users in different network segments are reporting that they are unable to access the application.

What must be enabled to allow an interface to forward multicast traffic?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
You must enable IP multicast for the virtual router, configure Protocol Independent Multicast (PIM) on the ingress and egress interfaces, and configure Internet Group Management Protocol (IGMP) on receiver-facing interfaces.
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-1/pan-os-networking-admin/ip-multicast/configure-ip-multicast

Selected Answer: D
The nuance to this question is thus: to 'forward mcast traffic' (actual question) requires PIM, but for a receiver to join a group (different than the actual question) requires IGMP.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

Selected Answer: D
The answer is only one - D.
FW-1 will get the value from FW-DG1 while FW-2 will get the value from the Shared DG since no values are present in its parent DGs.
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/panorama/9-1/panorama-admin/manage-firewalls/manage-device-groups/manage-precedence-of-inherited-objects
This question appeared on PCNSE January 2023

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

Selected Answer: D
Agreed with chrisy0402, the FW-2 DGs are there to confuse you

Updated link July 2023-
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/panorama/10-2/panorama-admin/manage-firewalls/manage-device-groups/manage-precedence-of-inherited-objects

Selected Answer: D
Device Groups take affect in reverse order. So if there are competing setting, the lowest Device Group in the hierarchy takes precedence. FW2 is not in the same hierarchy so inherets the Server 1 setting from the Shared Deviced Group.

Selected Answer: D
D only as chrisy042 has explained!

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Review the screenshots and consider the following information:

• FW-1 is assigned to the FW-1_DG device group and FW-2 is assigned to OFFICE_FW_DG
• There are no objects configured in REGIONAL_DG and OFFICE_FW_DG device groups

Which IP address will be pushed to the firewalls inside Address Object Server-1?

choices.A:
Server-1 on FW-1 will have IP 2.2.2.2
Server-1 will not be pushed to FW-2
choices.D:
Server-1 on FW-1 will have IP 4.4.4.4
Server-1 on FW-2 will have IP 1.1.1.1
choices.C:
Server-1 on FW-1 will have IP 1.1.1.1
Server-1 will not be pushed to FW-2
choices.B:
Server-1 on FW-1 will have IP 3.3.3.3
Server-1 will not be pushed to FW-2

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Given the Sample Log Forwarding Profile shown, which two statements are true? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
A: is sure correct.
C: will only be correct if the operator between 192.168.0.0/16 & 10.0.0.0/8 is an "OR" and not an "AND" source can't be from both subnets, it's either or, not both

comments.content: This means that only A is correct !

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
Sadly, none of these choices are technically correct. 
@obatel pointed out that the RFC 1918 filter uses AND condition instead of OR
@BTSeeYa pointed out that A stated 'all traffic' instead of 'all traffic logs'

A would be correct if they say 'all traffic logs' instead of simply 'all traffic'
B would be correct if they said email instead of Panorama
C would be correct if the RFC 1918 filter used OR instead of AND
D would be correct if they change the subnet to one that fell within the RFC 1918 filter AND if they referred to 'traffic logs'

Since A and C are the closest to correct choices, I guess that's what I'd choose on the test? [i just hope I don't see too many questions like this one on my test]

Selected Answer: AC
A isn't even technically correct, the way they have the answer written. These test makers need to do better. Instead of "All traffic", it should say "All Traffic logs". The way they wrote that suggests that all logs would be sent to the Syslog server.
There must be a typo with D. They probably want to say 172.16/24. In which case, A and D would be correct

Selected Answer: AC
A, C are correct
Only A is correct. All the others are wrong.

A and C are correct:
A-192.168.100.0/24 are send to Syslog. 
C-RFC 1918 defines private IP addressing, so Private subnets are sending to PN/Cortex DL.

Selected Answer: AC
AC
B is not correct as it is sent externally not to Panorama
D is not correct as it is 172.12 (not 172.16)
That's right. Good catch, obatel.

choices.C: All traffic logs from RFC 1918 subnets are logged to Panorama / Cortex Data Lake.
choices.B: All threats are logged to Panorama.
choices.A: All traffic from source network 192.168.100.0/24 is sent to an external syslog target.
choices.D: All traffic from source network 172.12.0.0/24 is sent to Panorama / Cortex Data Lake.
